raw_text:
O'Connor aims to grab opportunity
 
 Johnny O'Connor is determined to make a big impression when he makes his RBS Six Nations debut for Ireland against Scotland on Saturday.
 
 The Wasps flanker replaces Denis Leamy but O'Connor knows that the Munster man will be pushing hard for a recall for the following game against England. "It's a 'horses for courses' selection really," said O'Connor. "There's a lot of competition here and I can't just drag my heels around if I don't get picked." It looks a definite head-to-head battle between himself and 23-year-old Leamy - three stone heavier than O'Connor - for the number seven role against the world champions. Nonetheless, all O'Connor is currently concerned about is making an impression while winning his third cap.
 
 "Missing the Italian game was disappointing certainly, but you can't dwell on these things - it's part and parcel of rugby. "Denis has been playing really well and deserved his opportunity. "It's a good situation to be in if there are good players around you, pushing for a place in the side." O'Connor, who celebrated his 25th birthday on Wednesday, was touted by Wasps director of rugby Warren Gatland as a possible 2005 Lions Test openside as far back as last September. And his reputation as a breakdown scavenger and heavy hitter has seen him come to the forefront of O'Sullivan's mind for the Scottish tussle. O'Connor added: "It will be interesting to see how situations on the deck is reffed, with the new laws having come in.
 
 "Obviously the breakdown a big part of what I do on the pitch so I'm hoping to hold some influence there against what is a very solid Scottish pack." O'Connor will be winning his third cap after making his debut in the victory over South Africa last November.
llama3.2:1b: Johnny O'Connor replaces Denis Leamy for Ireland's RBS Six Nations game against Scotland, and aims to make an impression while pushing for a recall. He faces competition from 23-year-old Leamy, who is three stone heavier than him, but is concerned about making his debut rather than dwelling on past disappointments.
llama3.2:3b: Johnny O'Connor aims to make an impression in his RBS Six Nations debut for Ireland against Scotland, aware that Denis Leamy may push him out of contention for the next game against England. O'Connor acknowledges the competition but is focused on winning his third cap and making a positive contribution, particularly at the breakdown.
gemma2:2b: Johnny O'Connor, a Wasps flanker, will make his RBS Six Nations debut for Ireland against Scotland on Saturday. He replaces Denis Leamy and acknowledges strong competition for the number seven jersey.  O'Connor hopes to impress while also competing with Leamy for selection in future matches. The 25-year-old is known for his breakdown prowess and has been highlighted as a potential Lions Test player.  He will be playing his third match since making his debut against South Africa last November.
qwen2.5:0.5b: O'Connor aims to make an impact as he makes his RBS Six Nations debut for Ireland against Scotland on Saturday. Johnny O'Connor replaces Denis Leamy, but knows the Munster man will push hard for a recall and hopes to secure a good game. He faces three stone heavier players than himself at number seven in England vs. Italy, where it's part of the Rugby World Cup schedule. O'Connor has enjoyed playing well recently, and is looking forward to making an impression while winning his third cap.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Johnny O'Connor aims to impress with his RBS Six Nations debut for Ireland, facing competition from 23-year-old Leamy despite missing an Italian game due to lack of focus and enjoying a positive reputation ahead of the match against Scotland.
qwen2.5:3b: Johnny O'Connor aims to make an impact for Ireland in their Six Nations match against Scotland, replacing Denis Leamy who was selected instead. Both players compete for the number seven position. O'Connor highlights competition and emphasizes not dwelling on missed opportunities, crediting Leamy's performance. At 25, O'Connor has potential as a future Lions Test openside. His reputation as a breakdown player is noted, especially in light of new referee laws coming into effect against a strong Scottish pack. He expresses hope to influence the game with his skills. O'Connor's third Ireland cap comes from his November victory over South Africa.

"You missed the Italian game certainly, but you can't dwell on these things - it's part and parcel of rugby. Denis has been playing really well and deserved his opportunity."

smollm:1.7b: O'Connor aims to grab opportunity by playing well and pushing for a place in the side, while also focusing on the big game against Scotland. He is determined to make a good impression and win his third cap.

tinyllama:1.1b: Johnny O'Connor is determined to make an impression on his upcoming appearance in the RBS Six Nations against Scotland, aiming to grab a spot in the side through a competitive selection process. Despite playing for Wasps as a flaky flanker, he knows there will be fierce competition for a place among Ireland's frontline players, with 23-year-old Denis Leamy also in contention for one of the roles at fullback. O'Connor is currently focused on making an impression while winning his third cap for Ireland's Test team against Scotland, especially considering there are several experienced heavy hitters and breakdown scavengers waiting in the wings. Despite losing a tough Italian match, O'Connor was confident of finding his place in the side, citing the opportunities for players like Leamy to show their worth.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Johnny O'Connor, Wasps flanker, has been given a rare opportunity to make an impression during his first RBS Six Nations appearance against Scotland on Saturday. The young Irishman is determined to make the most of this golden chance and prove himself as a potential starter for the future. Despite facing a competitive battle with 23-year-old Denis Leamy, who was recruited to play in the number seven role against England next month, O'Connor has no intention of sitting back and allowing his teammates to catch up. Instead, he is focusing on making the most of his opportunity while honing his skills at the breakdown area.

O'Connor admits that missing Italy's Italian game was disappointing but he feels fortunate to be in a position where he can contribute positively. Although there are always competitors for spots on the team, O'Connor is determined to make his mark and impress Wasps director of rugby Warren Gatland. His reputation as a heavy hitter who can break down opposition defenses has made him an ideal candidate for the Scottish tussle this weekend.

The Wasps flanker also expresses interest in learning from former Irish international, Cian Healy, and is looking forward to contributing his skills to the team. O'Connor will be making his debut against Scotland on Saturday, hoping to hold some influence on the field against a strong Scottish pack. The young player has already made an impression on the Wasps teammates by securing a place in their lineup and proving himself as a worthy competitor during his first Six Nations appearance.
